  1 dir = File.dirname(__FILE__)
  2 $LOAD_PATH << dir unless $LOAD_PATH.include?(dir)

  4 # = Haml (XHTML Abstraction Markup Language)
  5 # 
  6 # Haml is a markup language
  7 # that's used to cleanly and simply describe the XHTML of any web document,
  8 # without the use of inline code.
  9 # Haml functions as a replacement
 10 # for inline page templating systems such as PHP, ERB, and ASP. 
 11 # However, Haml avoids the need for explicitly coding XHTML into the template, 
 12 # because it is actually an abstract description of the XHTML,
 13 # with some code to generate dynamic content.
 14 # 
 15 # == Features
 16 # 
 17 # * Whitespace active
 18 # * Well-formatted markup
 19 # * DRY
 20 # * Follows CSS conventions
 21 # * Integrates Ruby code
 22 # * Implements Rails templates with the .haml extension
 23 #
 24 # == Using Haml
 25 #
 26 # Haml can be used in two ways:
 27 # as a plugin for Ruby on Rails,
 28 # and as a standalong Ruby module.
 29 #
 30 # === Rails
 31 # 
 32 # Haml is most commonly used as a plugin.
 33 # It can be installed as a plugin using the Rails plugin installer:
 34 # 
 35 #   ./script/plugin install http://svn.hamptoncatlin.com/haml/tags/stable
 36 #
 37 # Once it's installed, all view files with the ".haml" extension
 38 # will be compiled using Haml.
 39 #
 40 # You can access instance variables in Haml templates
 41 # the same way you do in ERb templates.
 42 # Helper methods are also available in Haml templates.
 43 # For example:
 44 # 
 45 #   # file: app/controllers/movies_controller.rb
 46 # 
 47 #   class MoviesController < ApplicationController
 48 #     def index
 49 #       @title = "Teen Wolf"
 50 #     end
 51 #   end
 52 # 
 53 #   # file: app/views/movies/index.haml
 54 # 
 55 #   #content
 56 #    .title
 57 #      %h1= @title
 58 #      = link_to 'Home', home_url
 59 # 
 60 # may be compiled to:
 61 # 
 62 #   <div id='content'>
 63 #     <div class='title'>
 64 #       <h1>Teen Wolf</h1>
 65 #       <a href='/'>Home</a>
 66 #     </div>
 67 #   </div>
 68 #
 69 # === Ruby Module
 70 #
 71 # Haml can also be used completely separately from Rails and ActionView.
 72 # To do this, install the gem with RubyGems:
 73 #
 74 #   gem install haml
 75 #
 76 # You can then use it by including the "haml" gem in Ruby code,
 77 # and using Haml::Engine like so:
 78 #
 79 #   engine = Haml::Engine.new("%p Haml code!")
 80 #   engine.render #=> "<p>Haml code!</p>\n"
 81 # 
 82 # == Characters with meaning to Haml
 83 # 
 84 # Various characters, when placed at a certain point in a line,
 85 # instruct Haml to render different types of things.
 86 # 
 87 # === XHTML Tags
 88 # 
 89 # These characters render XHTML tags.
 90 # 
 91 # ==== %
 92 # 
 93 # 
 94 # The percent character is placed at the beginning of a line.
 95 # It's followed immediately by the name of an element,
 96 # then optionally by modifiers (see below), a space,
 97 # and text to be rendered inside the element.
 98 # It creates an element in the form of <tt><element></element></tt>.
 99 # For example:
100 # 
101 #   %one
102 #     %two
103 #       %three Hey there
104 # 
105 # is compiled to:
106 # 
107 #   <one>
108 #     <two>
109 #       <three>Hey there</three>
110 #     </two>
111 #   </one>
112 # 
113 # Any string is a valid element name;
114 # Haml will automatically generate opening and closing tags for any element.
115 # 
116 # ==== {}
117 # 
118 # Brackets represent a Ruby hash
119 # that is used for specifying the attributes of an element.
120 # It is literally evaluated as a Ruby hash,
121 # so logic will work in it and local variables may be used.
122 # Quote characters within the attribute
123 # will be replaced by appropriate escape sequences.
124 # The hash is placed after the tag is defined.
125 # For example:
126 # 
127 #   %head{ :name => "doc_head" }
128 #     %script{ 'type' => "text/" + "javascript",
129 #              :src   => "javascripts/script_#{2 + 7}" }
130 # 
131 # is compiled to:
132 # 
133 #   <head name="doc_head">
134 #     <script src='javascripts/script_9' type='text/javascript'>
135 #     </script>
136 #   </head>
137 # 
138 # ==== []
139 # 
140 # Square brackets follow a tag definition and contain a Ruby object
141 # that is used to set the class and id of that tag.
142 # The class is set to the object's class
143 # (transformed to use underlines rather than camel case)
144 # and the id is set to the object's class, followed by its id.
145 # Because the id of an object is normally an obscure implementation detail,
146 # this is most useful for elements that represent instances of Models.
147 # For example:
148 # 
149 #   # file: app/controllers/users_controller.rb
150 # 
151 #   def show
152 #     @user = CrazyUser.find(15)
153 #   end
154 # 
155 #   # file: app/views/users/show.haml
156 # 
157 #   %div[@user]
158 #     %bar[290]/
159 #     Hello!
160 # 
161 # is compiled to:
162 # 
163 #   <div class="crazy_user" id="crazy_user_15">
164 #     <bar class="fixnum" id="fixnum_581" />
165 #     Hello!
166 #   </div>
167 # 
168 # This is based off of DHH's SimplyHelpful syntax,
169 # as presented at RailsConf Europe 2006.
170 # 
171 # ==== /
172 # 
173 # The forward slash character, when placed at the end of a tag definition,
174 # causes the tag to be self-closed.
175 # For example:
176 # 
177 #   %br/
178 #   %meta{'http-equiv' => 'Content-Type', :content => 'text/html'}/
179 # 
180 # is compiled to:
181 # 
182 #   <br />
183 #   <meta http-equiv='Content-Type' content='text/html' />
184 #
185 # Some tags are automatically closed, as long as they have no content.
186 # +meta+, +img+, +link+, +script+, +br+, and +hr+ tags are closed by default.
187 # This list can be customized by setting the <tt>:autoclose</tt> option (see below).
188 # For example:
189 #
190 #   %br
191 #   %meta{'http-equiv' => 'Content-Type', :content => 'text/html'}
192 #
193 # is also compiled to:
194 #
195 #   <br />
196 #   <meta http-equiv='Content-Type' content='text/html' />
197 # 
198 # ==== . and #
199 # 
200 # The period and pound sign are borrowed from CSS.
201 # They are used as shortcuts to specify the <tt>class</tt>
202 # and <tt>id</tt> attributes of an element, respectively.
203 # Multiple class names can be specified in a similar way to CSS,
204 # by chaining the class names together with periods.
205 # They are placed immediately after the tag and before an attributes hash.
206 # For example:
207 # 
208 #   %div#things
209 #     %span#rice Chicken Fried
210 #     %p.beans{ :food => 'true' } The magical fruit
211 #     %h1.class.otherclass#id La La La
212 # 
213 # is compiled to:
214 # 
215 #   <div id='things'>
216 #     <span id='rice'>Chicken Fried</span>
217 #     <p class='beans' food='true'>The magical fruit</p>
218 #     <h1 class='class otherclass' id='id'>La La La</h1>
219 #   </div>
220 # 
221 # And,
222 # 
223 #   #content
224 #     .articles
225 #       .article.title
226 #         Doogie Howser Comes Out
227 #       .article.date
228 #         2006-11-05
229 #       .article.entry
230 #         Neil Patrick Harris would like to dispel any rumors that he is straight
231 # 
232 # is compiled to:
233 # 
234 #   <div id="content">
235 #     <div class="articles">
236 #       <div class="article title">Doogie Howser Comes Out</div>
237 #       <div class="article date">2006-11-05</div>
238 #       <div class="article entry">
239 #         Neil Patrick Harris would like to dispel any rumors that he is straight
240 #       </div>
241 #     </div>
242 #   </div>
243 # 
244 # ==== Implicit Div Elements
245 # 
246 # Because the div element is used so often, it is the default element.
247 # If you only define a class and/or id using the <tt>.</tt> or <tt>#</tt> syntax,
248 # a div element is automatically used.
249 # For example:
250 # 
251 #   #collection
252 #     .item
253 #       .description What a cool item!
254 # 
255 # is the same as:
256 # 
257 #   %div{:id => collection}
258 #     %div{:class => 'item'}
259 #       %div{:class => 'description'} What a cool item!
260 # 
261 # and is compiled to:
262 # 
263 #   <div id='collection'>
264 #     <div class='item'>Broken record album</div>
265 #     <div class='description'>What a cool item!</div>
266 #   </div>
267 # 
268 # ==== =
269 # 
270 # <tt>=</tt> is placed at the end of a tag definition,
271 # after class, id, and attribute declarations.
272 # It's just a shortcut for inserting Ruby code into an element.
273 # It works the same as <tt>=</tt> without a tag:
274 # it inserts the result of the Ruby code into the template.
275 # However, if the result is short enough,
276 # it is displayed entirely on one line.
277 # For example:
278 # 
279 #   %p= "hello"
280 # 
281 # is not quite the same as:
282 # 
283 #   %p
284 #     = "hello"
285 # 
286 # It's compiled to:
287 # 
288 #   <p>hello</p>
289 # 
290 # === XHTML Helpers
291 # 
292 # ==== No Special Character
293 # 
294 # If no special character appears at the beginning of a line,
295 # the line is rendered as plain text.
296 # For example:
297 # 
298 #   %gee
299 #     %whiz
300 #       Wow this is cool!
301 # 
302 # is compiled to:
303 # 
304 #   <gee>
305 #     <whiz>
306 #       Wow this is cool!
307 #     </whiz>
308 #   </gee>
309 # 
310 # ==== !!!
311 # 
312 # When describing XHTML documents with Haml,
313 # you can have a document type or XML prolog generated automatically
314 # by including the characters <tt>!!!</tt>.
315 # For example:
316 # 
317 #   !!! XML
318 #   !!!
319 #   %html
320 #     %head
321 #       %title Myspace
322 #     %body
323 #       %h1 I am the international space station
324 #       %p Sign my guestbook
325 # 
326 # is compiled to:
327 # 
328 #   <?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8" ?>
329 #   <!DOCTYPE html PUBLIC "-//W3C//DTD XHTML 1.0 Transitional//EN" "http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-transitional.dtd">
330 #   <html>
331 #     <head>
332 #       <title>Myspace</title>
333 #     </head>
334 #     <body>
335 #       <h1>I am the international space station</h1>
336 #       <p>Sign my guestbook</p>
337 #     </body>
338 #   </html>
339 # 
340 # You can also specify the version and type of XHTML after the <tt>!!!</tt>.
341 # XHTML 1.0 Strict, Transitional, and Frameset and XHTML 1.1 are supported.
342 # The default version is 1.0 and the default type is Transitional.
343 # For example:
344 # 
345 #   !!! 1.1
346 # 
347 # is compiled to:
348 # 
349 #   <!DOCTYPE html PUBLIC "-//W3C//DTD XHTML 1.1//EN" "http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml11/DTD/xhtml11.dtd">
350 # 
351 # and
352 # 
353 #   !!! Strict
354 # 
355 # is compiled to:
356 # 
357 #   <!DOCTYPE html PUBLIC "-//W3C//DTD XHTML 1.0 Strict//EN" "http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml1/DTD/xhtml1-strict.dtd">
358 # 
359 # If you're not using the UTF-8 characterset for your document,
360 # you can specify which encoding should appear
361 # in the XML prolog in a similar way.
362 # For example:
363 # 
364 #   !!! XML iso-8859-1
365 # 
366 # is compiled to:
367 # 
368 #   <?xml version="1.0" encoding="iso-8859-1" ?>
369 # 
370 # ==== /
371 # 
372 # The forward slash character, when placed at the beginning of a line,
373 # wraps all text after it in an HTML comment.
374 # For example:
375 # 
376 #   %billabong
377 #     / This is the billabong element
378 #     I like billabongs!
379 # 
380 # is compiled to:
381 # 
382 #   <billabong>
383 #     <!-- This is the billabong element -->
384 #     I like billabongs!
385 #   </billabong>
386 # 
387 # The forward slash can also wrap indented sections of code. For example:
388 # 
389 #   /
390 #     %p This doesn't render...
391 #     %div
392 #       %h1 Because it's commented out!
393 # 
394 # is compiled to:
395 # 
396 #   <!--
397 #     <p>This doesn't render...</p>
398 #     <div>
399 #       <h1>Because it's commented out!</h1>
400 #     </div>
401 #   -->
402 # 
403 # You can also use Internet Explorer conditional comments
404 # (about)[http://www.quirksmode.org/css/condcom.html]
405 # by enclosing the condition in square brackets after the <tt>/</tt>.
406 # For example:
407 # 
408 #   /[if IE]
409 #     %a{ :href => 'http://www.mozilla.com/en-US/firefox/' }
410 #       %h1 Get Firefox
411 # 
412 # is compiled to:
413 # 
414 #   <!--[if IE]>
415 #     <a href='http://www.mozilla.com/en-US/firefox/'>
416 #       <h1>Get Firefox</h1>
417 #     </a>
418 #   <![endif]-->
419 # 
420 # ==== \
421 # 
422 # The backslash character escapes the first character of a line,
423 # allowing use of otherwise interpreted characters as plain text.
424 # For example:
425 # 
426 #   %title
427 #     = @title
428 #     \- MySite
429 # 
430 # is compiled to:
431 # 
432 #   <title>
433 #     MyPage
434 #     - MySite
435 #   </title>
436 # 
437 # ==== |
438 # 
439 # The pipe character designates a multiline string.
440 # It's placed at the end of a line
441 # and means that all following lines that end with <tt>|</tt>
442 # will be evaluated as though they were on the same line.
443 # For example:
444 # 
445 #   %whoo
446 #     %hoo I think this might get |
447 #       pretty long so I should |
448 #       probably make it |
449 #       multiline so it doesn't |
450 #       look awful. |
451 #     %p This is short.
452 # 
453 # is compiled to:
454 # 
455 #   <whoo>
456 #     <hoo>
457 #       I think this might get pretty long so I should probably make it multiline so it doesn't look awful.
458 #     </hoo>
459 #   </whoo>
460 #
461 # ==== :
462 #
463 # The colon character designates a filter.
464 # This allows you to pass an indented block of text as input
465 # to another filtering program and add the result to the output of Haml.
466 # The syntax is simply a colon followed by the name of the filter.
467 # For example,
468 #
469 #   %p
470 #     :markdown
471 #       Textile
472 #       =======
473 #
474 #       Hello, *World*
475 #
476 # is compiled to
477 #
478 #   <p>
479 #     <h1>Textile</h1>
480 #
481 #     <p>Hello, <em>World</em></p>
482 #   </p>
483 #
484 # Haml has the following filters defined:
485 #
486 # [plain]     Does not parse the filtered text.
487 #             This is useful for large blocks of text without HTML tags,
488 #             when you don't want lines starting with <tt>.</tt> or <tt>-</tt>
489 #             to be parsed.
490 #
491 # [ruby]      Parses the filtered text with the normal Ruby interpreter.
492 #             All output sent to <tt>$stdout</tt>, like with +puts+,
493 #             is output into the Haml document.
494 #             Not available if the <tt>suppress_eval</tt> option is set to true.
495 #
496 # [preserve]  Inserts the filtered text into the template with whitespace preserved.
497 #             <tt>preserve</tt>d blocks of text aren't indented,
498 #             and newlines are replaced with the HTML escape code for newlines,
499 #             to preserve nice-looking output.
500 #
501 # [erb]       Parses the filtered text with ERB, like an RHTML template.
502 #             Not available if the <tt>suppress_eval</tt> option is set to true.
503 #             At the moment, this doesn't support access to variables
504 #             defined by Ruby on Rails or Haml code.
505 #
506 # [sass]      Parses the filtered text with Sass to produce CSS output.
507 #
508 # [redcloth]  Parses the filtered text with RedCloth (http://whytheluckystiff.net/ruby/redcloth),
509 #             which uses both Textile and Markdown syntax.
510 #             Only works if RedCloth is installed.
511 #
512 # [textile]   Parses the filtered text with Textile (http://www.textism.com/tools/textile).
513 #             Only works if RedCloth is installed.
514 #
515 # [markdown]  Parses the filtered text with Markdown (http://daringfireball.net/projects/markdown).
516 #             Only works if RedCloth or BlueCloth (http://www.deveiate.org/projects/BlueCloth)
517 #             is installed
518 #             (BlueCloth takes precedence if both are installed).
519 #
520 # You can also define your own filters (see Setting Options, below).
521 # 
522 # === Ruby evaluators
523 # 
524 # ==== =
525 # 
526 # The equals character is followed by Ruby code,
527 # which is evaluated and the output inserted into the document as plain text.
528 # For example:
529 # 
530 #   %p
531 #     = ['hi', 'there', 'reader!'].join " "
532 #     = "yo"
533 # 
534 # is compiled to:
535 # 
536 #   <p>
537 #     hi there reader!
538 #     yo
539 #   </p>
540 # 
541 # ==== -
542 # 
543 # The hyphen character makes the text following it into "silent script":
544 # Ruby script that is evaluated, but not output.
545 # 
546 # <b>It is not recommended that you use this widely;
547 # almost all processing code and logic should be restricted
548 # to the Controller, the Helper, or partials.</b>
549 # 
550 # For example:
551 # 
552 #   - foo = "hello"
553 #   - foo << " there"
554 #   - foo << " you!"
555 #   %p= foo
556 # 
557 # is compiled to:
558 # 
559 #   <p>
560 #     hello there you!
561 #   </p>
562 # 
563 # ===== Blocks
564 # 
565 # Ruby blocks, like XHTML tags, don't need to be explicitly closed in Haml.
566 # Rather, they're automatically closed, based on indentation.
567 # A block begins whenever the indentation is increased
568 # after a silent script command.
569 # It ends when the indentation decreases
570 # (as long as it's not an +else+ clause or something similar).
571 # For example:
572 # 
573 #   - (42...47).each do |i|
574 #     %p= i
575 #   %p See, I can count!
576 # 
577 # is compiled to:
578 # 
579 #   <p>
580 #     42
581 #   </p>
582 #   <p>
583 #     43
584 #   </p>
585 #   <p>
586 #     44
587 #   </p>
588 #   <p>
589 #     45
590 #   </p>
591 #   <p>
592 #     46
593 #   </p>
594 # 
595 # Another example:
596 # 
597 #   %p
598 #     - case 2
599 #     - when 1
600 #       = "1!"
601 #     - when 2
602 #       = "2?"
603 #     - when 3
604 #       = "3."
605 # 
606 # is compiled to:
607 # 
608 #   <p>
609 #     2?
610 #   </p>
611 # 
612 # == Haml Options
613 # 
614 # Options can be set by setting the hash <tt>Haml::Template.options</tt>
615 # from <tt>environment.rb</tt> in Rails,
616 # or by passing an options hash to Haml::Engine.
617 # Available options are:
618 # 
619 # [<tt>:suppress_eval</tt>] Whether or not attribute hashes and Ruby scripts
620 #                           designated by <tt>=</tt> or <tt>~</tt> should be
621 #                           evaluated. If this is true, said scripts are
622 #                           rendered as empty strings. Defaults to false.
623 # 
624 # [<tt>:precompiled</tt>]   A string containing a precompiled Haml template.
625 #                           If this is passed, <tt>template</tt> is ignored
626 #                           and no precompilation is done.
627 # 
628 # [<tt>:attr_wrapper</tt>]  The character that should wrap element attributes.
629 #                           This defaults to <tt>'</tt> (an apostrophe). Characters
630 #                           of this type within the attributes will be escaped
631 #                           (e.g. by replacing them with <tt>&apos;</tt>) if
632 #                           the character is an apostrophe or a quotation mark.
633 #
634 # [<tt>:filename</tt>]      The name of the Haml file being parsed.
635 #                           This is only used as information when exceptions are raised.
636 #                           This is automatically assigned when working through ActionView,
637 #                           so it's really only useful for the user to assign
638 #                           when dealing with Haml programatically.
639 #
640 # [<tt>:filters</tt>]       A hash of filters that can be applied to Haml code.
641 #                           The keys are the string names of the filters;
642 #                           the values are references to the classes of the filters.
643 #                           User-defined filters should always have lowercase keys,
644 #                           and should have:
645 #                           * An +initialize+ method that accepts one parameter,
646 #                             the text to be filtered.
647 #                           * A +render+ method that returns the result of the filtering.
648 # 
649 # [<tt>:locals</tt>]        The local variables that will be available within the
650 #                           template. For instance, if <tt>:locals</tt> is
651 #                           <tt>{ :foo => "bar" }</tt>, then within the template,
652 #                           <tt>= foo</tt> will produce <tt>bar</tt>.
653 #
654 # [<tt>:autoclose</tt>]     A list of tag names that should be automatically self-closed
655 #                           if they have no content.
656 #                           Defaults to <tt>['meta', 'img', 'link', 'script', 'br', 'hr']</tt>.
657 #
658 module Haml; end
659 
660 require 'haml/engine'

Generated using the rcov code coverage analysis tool for Ruby version 0.8.0.
